description: From Middle English chymeney, chymney, chymne, from Old French cheminee, from Late Latin camīnāta, from Latin camīnus, from Ancient Greek κάμῑνος (kámīnos, “furnace”). Doublet of chimenea.

entries.meaning: A vertical tube or hollow column used to emit environmentally polluting gaseous and solid matter (including but not limited to by-products of burning carbon- or hydrocarbon-based fuels); a flue.
The glass flue surrounding the flame of an oil lamp.
(Britain) The smokestack of a steam locomotive.
A narrow cleft in a rock face; a narrow vertical cave passage.
(Northern Ireland, slang) A black eye; a shiner.

verbs.description: chimney (third-person singular simple present chimneys, present participle chimneying, simple past and past participle chimneyed)

entries.meaning: (climbing) To negotiate a chimney (narrow vertical cave passage) by pushing against the sides with back, feet, hands, etc.
